{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3091902,"name":"Riley","username":"Riley_Donat","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-10-25T16:31:26.176Z","cooked":"

Our team is using some SRX Mag encoders. The quadrature encoder outputs an A and B signal which we are reading through the dio ports on the rio. When we wired everything up we had some uncertainty as to which channel was which when looking at the wires coming out of the encoder. I guess my question is theoretically if we mixed them up and channel A is going to the dio port where we are trying to read B and vice versa for B, what would happen? Our thoughts were that the direction of the encoder would be inverted but we aren’t real sure.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2022-10-25T16:32:47.645Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":416570,"topic_slug":"quadrature-encoder-channels-a-and-b","display_username":"Riley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51129,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/quadrature-encoder-channels-a-and-b/416570/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3091908,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-10-25T16:51:21.791Z","cooked":"

Yes. It would appear to be going backwards. Assuming you’re using the 10-pin ribbon connector, the wires follow the pinout in the manual:

store.ctr-electronics.com

Magnetic%20Encoder%20User's%20Guide.pdf

You’re only looking for pins 2, 5, 7 and 10. If you hook up pins 2 and 10 (power and ground) then look at 5 and 7 with a multimeter or logic probe (or just an LED connected with a resistor to ground), you ought to be able to tell which one is which fairly easily.

The other reply is correct, but I’ll also mention the lazy programmer solution: hook it up however, then do a little testing to see if it’s going the way you want. If not, then either toss in negative signs where you need them, or if you’re using the Encoder class (not a class from the CTRE library) set the reverseDirection parameter to true (in C++, but should be similar in the other languages).

Thanks. We are pretty confident we got the right pins from the encoder so we will just have to check the sensor direction we get and invert accordingly in code. I appreciate the replies, thanks for the help.
